answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
You might also search Who's Who and email other Assistant-to's and see if they could email a copy of their job description. Other resources to consider might be the Internship Toolkit (interns often do the work of an assistant-to):
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_resources/internship_toolkit
And look at the Management Fellow work plans in the job descriptions topic area:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/topic_Documents/147/job_descriptions
If the duties match anything you're looking for, you could contact those communities to see if they have anything they can share.
There might also be some articles in PM Magazine. We've got a "next generation" compilation that I recall has some nuts/bolts articles.
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_resources/news_reports_presentations/pm_nextgen
When you're done, please share! I think you may be cutting new ground here.

answers.author: Thomas Chumbley
answers.text:
The bottom line: there ain't no 'best practices' per se by itself. I am sorry to go fundamental on you but there are conventions of writing, and styles etc. In my opinion you must have a: cover, title page, table of contents, glossary of terms and a statement of purpose. Everything else will need to be geared to that statement of purpose. Allow me instead to give you a process.   
Brainstorm about what you think is important to go into the document.  
 Have a recording device and do a quick version of qualitative research to find out what is important to stakeholders concerning the document.  
the one's who asked you to write it and their expectations for the document   
 the one's who will have to use it   
and talking with those who have recently entered as Assistants and have that fresh memory of information gaps or trouble spots 
Do a comparative analysis of everything you have at this point and see where additional discussions with others will be important to obtain more information/data concerning items you may know less about but will need to write about.   
 Organize what major topics will now need to go into the document-what will essentially be your table of contents.   
 Write with the accuracy, objectivity, and punctuation of a peer-reviewed scholarly journal. But in style write simply & concisely more like an executive summary.   
 Given your audience, take complicated matters and break them down into steps [this may be their only source for this critical information] but without insulting their intelligence.

author: Joshua Wheatley
text:
I've been asked to (1) write a policies and procedures manual specific to an Assistant to the City Administrator position and (2) research best practices in writing this type of manual.  The purpose of this type of manual would be to ease transitions by enabling a new hire to step into the job and quickly "learn the ropes."  
A sample of this type of position-specific manual, or any other advice that you can provide, would be greatly appreciated.
title: Position-specific Manuals
